metadata.synopsis: Kurt Russell plays hard-boiled truck driver Jack Burton, who gets caught in a bizarre conflict within, and underneath, San Francisco's Chinatown. An ancient Chinese prince and Chinatown crime lord has kidnapped a beautiful green-eyed woman, who is the fiancee to Jack's best friend. Jack must help his friend rescue the girl before the evil Lo Pan uses her to break the ancient curse that keeps him a fleshless and immortal spirit.

reviews: For every genuine martial arts feat or gruesome monstrosity, there's a sequence of riotous slapstick to counter the brief seriousness.
It is an odd, sometimes-nightmarish delight and one that rewards multiple viewings by those brave or foolish enough to return to this cinematic middle finger to the Hollywood mainstream.

A box office bomb that also had to endure a critical mauling, this subsequently enjoyed a healthy life on video and is now considered by many fanboys to be an exemplary action-fantasy-comedy. The truth actually rests between those two extremes.
This is just one of those movies that... lives and breathes on the back of its star.
I knew we would have fun talking about it, but this movie was so crazy it almost feels unfair...it's so out of pocket.
Violent 1980s martial-arts movie is a campy guilty pleasure.
Contains the single drop-dead funniest moment in all of Carpenter's filmography.
Works as a stand alone classic that features John Carpenter at his best.
This is a bizarre, fun, action packed film, filled with wild characters and an adventurous, imaginative and campy spirit.
Benefits from a rollicking wise-ass performance from Kurt Russell but otherwise falls limp courtesy of too many corny gags.
A film to embody the Eighties, and justify them

A 'B'-movie-style Western meets Eastern, a supernatural 'chopsocky' fantasy with leading man Kurt Russell doing a feature-length impression of a dead movie star. Put that in your pipe and smoke it. [Blu-ray]
The high-octane action comedy takes all that was worthwhile from decades of B-flicks and distills it into a maximum-concentration explosion of cinematic TNT.
Imperfect, yes...but still great cultish fun with Kurt Russell.
Russell and Carpenter make a great team.
